subsection.p: A Scene, like a scene in a play, is a way of breaking up the action in a game into bits that the GM can design and share and reason about.

Some scenes will have to be extemporaneous, ad lib affairs, that the GM throws together on the fly. This chapter is more about planned scenes where the GM has the luxury of planning. Combat can also be regarded as a scene, so the points made in this chapter may apply. But it is different enough to warrant its own examination in a following chapter.

We would suggest that a good scene has the following parts to it:
A Purpose, or a dramatic question
Conflict which may be combat, but might also be traps, hazards, diplomacy,
A dilemma, a choice for the players to make
One or more Time Constraints,
Stakes or Rewards,
Multiple outcomes from favourable to unfavourable, and
Pointers .. where to next in case players get stuck?

If the game seems to slowed down, go with Raymond Chandlers advice: "When in doubt, have a man come through a door with a crossbow in his hand."
Embrace episodic game play. Cut out exploring store-rooms, uneventful travel.
